article.description:
Marquette hopes its victory over Charlotte on
Thursday is the start of another long home winning streak.
article.headline: Versatile Wade puts together complete game for Eagles
article.linkText: Wade helps No. 11 Marquette start another streak
article.story: MILWAUKEE (AP) -- Marquette hopes its victory over Charlotte on Thursday is the start of another long home winning streak. Dwyane Wade scored 21 points, including 10 in a row during one stretch, and Robert Jackson had 15 as Marquette (No. 12 ESPN/USA Today; No. 12 Associated Press) beat Charlotte 75-67. The Golden Eagles (19-4, 10-2) rebounded from the 73-70 defeat last Saturday to Louisville that ended their 28-game home winning streak, dating back to 2001. The victory lifted Marquette a half-game ahead of Louisville atop the American Division of C-USA. ''I'm going to enjoy this for another 30 minutes and then move on,'' Marquette coach Tom Crean said. Crean lauded the versatile Wade, who had nine rebounds, five assists and three steals. ''He had a stellar performance at both ends,'' Crean said. ''He missed a couple of shots he usually makes, but he played with confidence and did a great job.'' Travis Diener had 12 points and Scott Merritt scored 11 points and had a game-high 10 rebounds for Marquette. Charlotte (10-13, 5-6), which beat Cincinnati 74-64 at home Saturday, has won only one C-USA game on the road this season. Demon Brown led the 49ers with 22 points and Curtis Withers added 11. ''Sometimes the road is a mental thing,'' Charlotte coach Bobby Lutz said. ''But tonight we didn't match the intensity we had against Cincinnati.'' Brown, who leads the nation with 5.1 3-pointers a game, went 6-for-17 from behind the arc against Marquette. He already has broken the C-USA record for 3s in a single season with 118. ''They did a great job of guarding him,'' Crean said. ''He made some tough, challenged 3s. I thought he had only one that was wide open.'' Marquette opened the second half with a 12-5 run, with Wade scoring seven of those points. The lead was extended to 55-39 when Diener hit a 3-pointer with 13 minutes to play. The 49ers, getting two 3-pointers from Brown, closed to seven points with 6:31 left before going scoreless for 2:26. A layup by Jackson and two free throws each by Wade and Diener made it 67-57 with 3:05 left. Brown's sixth 3-pointer was answered with a short jumper by Merritt and a three-point play by Jackson to make it 72-60. ''It got a little sloppy at the end and we were just happy to come out with the win,'' Merritt said. Trailing 16-14 with 8:30 left in the first half, Marquette hit four 3-pointers -- three by 6-foot-10 freshman Steve Novak and one by Diener -- en route to a 17-2 run and a 31-18 lead. Wade scored Marquette's final six points, making it 37-29 at halftime. Marquette had a 23-8 edge in rebounding in the first half, but Charlotte had 16 offensive rebounds in the second half while making things somewhat uneasy for the Golden Eagles. ''We really matched their effort on the boards and had a chance to get back in it,'' Lutz said of the 25-14 advantage off the glass in the final 20 minutes.
